creator: wlgivens@gmail.com
text:
After compiling Apache I receive the following error upon startup:

httpd: could not open document config file /etc/apache/httpd.conf

I checked the error_log/access_log files, nothing. Went ahead and checked 
syslog, also nothing. Then I decided to run gdb and received the same thing, 
nothing.

Out of desparation, believing it may have been something wrong with the rolled 
binaries, I reinstalled HTTP-2.0.53 [home rolled rpm] and upon running 'service 
apache start' recieved the exact same answer... any idea's as to whats going 
on? TIA

creator: jorton@redhat.com
text:
Most likely a permissions issue or similar.  Run 

  $ strace -e open httpd

and see what error code the relevant open() call fails with.  I've improved the
error message on the trunk.

creator: wlgivens@gmail.com
text:
Well I ran 'strace' and it turned up nada... I went through it a couple of 
times and couldn't find any files that it may have been missing... It may be 
reading the 'wrong' file version and that's what is causing the error, I don't 
know. Can you take a look at it and give me an idea whats going on? thanks...

Created attachment 14925
print error message if opening the config file fails

Please try the above patch - this reports the actual error message for this
failure case.
creator: jorton@redhat.com

text:
Well didn't need to add the patch. I was goofing around last night, checking 
out the strace that I generated and compared it to a strace of a gcc rolled rpm 
of Apache. I noticed that the Compaq C [ccc] binaries were hanging at 
libpthread.so and not loading any additional libs...

I reinstalled GLIBC-2.3.2 and then recompiled Apache and everything worked 
fine. I seemed that, possibly, the libpthread.[so.a] were pointing to the wrong 
locations [miss linked].

Apache is running like a top... thanks all. I should have posted the solution 
last night but it was late and my main thoughts were, "hitting the sack".
creator: wlgivens@gmail.com
jorton@redhat.com
text: OK.  Re-opening to mark as invalid...
